ArticleTitle.sentence: Salicylates inhibit lipopolysaccharide-induced transcriptional activation of the tissue factor gene in human monocytic cells.

event.clue: Salicylates inhibit lipopolysaccharide-induced transcriptional activation of the tissue factor gene in human monocytic cells.

AbstractText.sentence: Binding of plasma Factor VII/VIIa to the tissue factor (TF) receptor initiates the coagulation protease cascades.

event.clue: Binding of plasma Factor VII/VIIa to the tissue factor (TF) receptor initiates the coagulation protease cascades.

AbstractText.sentence: TF expression by circulating monocytes is associated with thrombotic and inflammatory complications in a variety of diseases.

event.clue: TF expression by circulating monocytes is associated with thrombotic and inflammatory complications in a variety of diseases.

AbstractText.sentence: Transcriptional activation of the human TF gene in monocytic cells exposed to bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is mediated by binding of c-Rel/p65 heterodimers to a kappa B site in the TF promoter.

event.clue: Transcriptional activation of the human TF gene in monocytic cells exposed to bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is mediated by binding of c-Rel/p65 heterodimers to a kappa B site in the TF promoter.

AbstractText.sentence: Here, we report that a family of anti-inflammatory agents, known as the salicylates, inhibited LPS induction of TF activity and TF gene transcription in human monocytes and monocytic THP-1 cells at clinically relevant doses.

AbstractText.sentence: Furthermore, sodium salicylate blocked the LPS-induced proteolytic degradation of I kappa B alpha, which prevented the nuclear translocation of c-Rel/p65 heterodimers.

AbstractText.sentence: In contrast, two other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, ibuprofen and indomethacin, did not inhibit LPS induction of the TF gene.

AbstractText.sentence: The clinical benefits of salicylates in the treatment of several diseases, including atherosclerosis and rheumatoid arthritis, may be related to their ability to reduce monocyte gene expression.
